section.title: Constant Acceleration Motion
section.p: The one-dimensional constant acceleration motion has many applications in practice. For instance, almost all problems of freely falling bodies near Earth is first done by assuming a constant acceleration. As we have done in this chapter, we will remain with one-dimensional situations, e.g., motion along a Cartesian axis, say the x axis.

illustrates a common setup for a constant-acceleration prblems. We denote the interval by \Delta t = t_f - t_i , the change in position by \Delta x = x_f-x_i , and change in velocity by \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} . In these problems, we are typically interested in change in position and velocity over some interval of time. We do not care about what happens AT OTHER INSTANTS as long as acceleration is same at all those instants.

figure.caption: Set up for constant acceleration motion along the x axis with unchanging a_x throughout the interval, i.e., constant acceleration along x axis. Here, subscript i refers to initial instant and f to the final instant.

sidebyside.p:
Since acceleration is constant during the interval, the change in velocity will simply be the product of acceleration and the duration.
\Delta v_x = a_x \Delta t.

section.p:
You can easily see from either thinking in terms of average acceleration or in terms of area-under-the-curve of a_x versus t as shown in or integral of a constant a_x. You can also write Eq. more explicitly to get the following equation.
v_{f,x} = v_{i,x} + a_x \left( t_f - t_i \right).
This formula for v_{f,x} will be same for any arbitrary instant t as the final instant. Let us denote by t the time at any arbitrary instant and v_x velocity at this arbitrary instant. Then.
v_{x} = v_{i,x} + a_x \left( t - t_i \right).
This says that velocity changes linearly with time, i.e., v_x(t) is a linear polynomial of t, i.e., a plot of v_x against time t will be a straight line.
v_x(t) = A + B t,
with
A = v_{i,x} - a_x t_i,\ \ \ B = a_x.

sidebyside.p:
Therefore, average velocity will simply be the average of initial and final velocities. This is correct only in the case of constant acceleration.
v_{\text{av},x} = \dfrac{v_{i,x} + v_{f,x}}{2}.

section.p:
Now, displacement can be given just by the product of average velocity and duration. Therefore,
\Delta x = v_{\text{av},x} \, \Delta t.

It is possible to eliminate \Delta t from these equations to obtain
v_{f,x}^2 = v_{i,x}^2 + 2 a_x \left( \Delta x \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-t-equation . It is also possible to eliminate v_{f,x} to obtain another useful equation:
\Delta x = v_{i,x} \Delta t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_x\left(\Delta t \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-v_f-equation.

Sign conventions. We use a sign convention to follow the directions of velocity and acceleration. The justification of these sign conventions will become clear after you learn vectors. The following diagrams clarify the sign assignments of velocity and acceleration.

sidebyside.p: The velocity v_x is positive if object is moving in the direction of positive axis and negative if in the opposite direction.
Acceleration a_x is positive in two situations: if either v_x is positive and speeding up OR v_x is negative and slowing down.
Acceleration a_x is negative in two situations: if either v_x is negative and speeding up OR v_x is positive and slowing down.

example.title: Constant Acceleration of a Car from Zero Velocity

statement.p: A car can accelerate from zero velocity to 30\text{ m/s} in 2.5\text{ s}.
(a) What is the acceleration of the car?
(b) What is the average velocity of the car during the time of acceleration?
(c) How far does the car travel during the 2.5\text{ s}?

solution.title: a
solution.p:
From the change in velocity we find
a = \dfrac{v_f - v_i}{t} = \dfrac{30 \text{ m/s} - 0}{2.5\text{ s}} = 12 \text{ m/s}^2.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Since acceleration is constant, average velocity will be average of initial and final velocities.
v_{av} = \dfrac{v_f + v_i}{2} = \dfrac{30 \text{ m/s} + 0}{2} = 15 \text{ m/s}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
From average velocity and duration, we get the displacement to be
x_f - x_i = v_{av} t = 15 \text{ m/s} \times 2.5 \text{ s} = 37.5 \text{ m}.

example.title: Predicting the Final Velocity in a Constant Acceleration Motion

statement.p: A skier is coming down a steep slope with a constant acceleration a = 3.0\text{ m/s}^2. If the speed of the skier at the top of the hill was 0 , what is his speed when he has skied a distance of 40 \text{ m} down the hill? Ignore the bumps on the hill.

solution.p:
Take the positive x axis to point down the hill. This will give us positive values for acceleration a_x and velocity v_x. For the sake of brevity, we will drop the coordinate subscript x from the symbols. From the problem statement, we can get the following.
a = 3.0\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ \Delta x = 40 \text{ m},\ \ v_i = 0,\ \ v_f = ?
The no-t-equation is perfect for this and gives
v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2 a \Delta x = 0 + 2 \times 3 \times 40 = 240.
Taking square root of both sides gives two values
v_f = \pm 15.5\text{ m/s}.
Its absolute value is speed v_{s}. Therefore v_s = 15.5\text{ m/s}.

example.title: Stopping Distance in a Constantly Decelerating Situation

statement.p: Suppose maximum deceleration of a particular car is 30.0\text{ m/s}^2. The car is moving at a steady pace at 40.0\text{ m/s} on a straight road. The driver notices a deer on the road and applies the maximum brake right away. How far from the front of the car the deer must be if the car must stop before it hits the deer?

solution.p:
Here, we are given that acceleration is in the opposite direction of initial velocity. So, if the initial velocity v_x is positive, the acceleration a_x will be negative. For brevity, I will drop x from the symbols. We have
v_i = 40.0 \text{ m/s}, \ \ v_f = 0, \ \ a = - 30.0 \text{ m/s}^2,
and we are asked to find \Delta x. Using the no-t-equation we get (I will omit units in the calculations.)
v_f^2 - v_i^2 = 2 a \Delta x \rightarrow 0 - 40^2 = -2 \times 30 \times \Delta x.
Note how the minus sign is necessary on the right for them to cancel out in this problem as it should. It should because, \Delta x should be positive since car is moving in the direction of positive x axis. Solving for \Delta x we get
\Delta x = 26.7\text{ m}.

statement.p: Starting from rest a box slides down an incline at a constant acceleration of 2\text{ m/s}^2 pointed down the incline (not vertically down).
(a) Find speed of the box at t = 1.5 sec.
(b) Find average velocity of the box between t = 0 and t =1.5 sec.
(c) Determine distance covered on the incline in 1.5 sec.
(d) Verify that the displacement during the 1.5-sec interval is equal to the product of the average velocity for the interval and the time interval.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Let us point +x axis down the incline. This will give
a_x = + 2\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ v_{ix} = 0,\ \ \Delta t = 1.5\text{ sec}\equiv t.

Therefore,
v_{fx} = v_{ix} + a_x t = 0 + 2\times 1.5 = 3.0\text{ m/s}.
This gives final speed equal to 3.0\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
For constant acceleration, average velocity is just the average of initial and final velocities.
v_\text{av,x} = \dfrac{v_{ix} + v_{fx}}{2} = 1.5\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
The displacement from initial velocity and accl will be
\Delta x = v_{ix} t + \dfrac{1}{2}a t^2 = 0 + \dfrac{1}{2}\times 2\times 1.5^2 = 2.25\text{ m}.

solution.title: d
solution.p:
Using average velocity and duration we verify
\Delta x = v_\text{av,x}\, t= 1.5\times 1.5 = 2.25\text{ m}.

example.title: Deceleration of a Hockey Puck While Moving up an Incline

statement.p: A hockey puck is hit up an incline. The puck slows down at a constant acceleration of magnitude 5\text{ m/s}^2 and stops after 1.2 sec.
(a) Find the initial velocity, i.e. the velocity of the puck immediately after leaving the stick.
(b) How far up the incline does the puck go before coming to rest?
(c) What is the velocity at t = 0.5\text{ sec}?
(d) Find the position of the puck at t = 0.5\text{ sec}.

answer.p: (a) 6.0\text{ m/s} pointed up incline, (b) 3.6\text{ m}, (c) 3.5\text{ m/s} pointed up incline, (d) 2.4\text{ m}.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Let +x axis be pointed up the incline. This makes a_x negative since puck's velocity will be in the positive x direction and the puck will be slowing down. We will also drop x from the subscript of symbols and write t in place of \Delta t.
a = - 5.0\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ t = 1.2\text{ sec},\ \ v_{f} = 0.

a From v_f = v_i + a t we get
v_{i} = v_{f} - a t = 0-(-5)\times 1.2 = 6.0\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
From \Delta x = v_{i} + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2, we get
\Delta x = 6\times 1.2 + \dfrac{1}{2}\times (-5)\times 1.2^2 = 3.6\text{ m}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
Now, t=0.5\text{ s} and v_{f}\ne 0. We can use v_{i} found above to calculate v_{f}.
v_{f} = v_{i} + a t = 6.0 + (-5)\times 0.5 = 3.5\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: d
solution.p:
The displacement
\Delta x \amp = \dfrac{v_{i} + v_{f}}{2}\, t \amp = \dfrac{6 + 3.5}{2}\times 0.5 = 2.4\text{ m}.
You can also answer this part by
\Delta x \amp = v_i t + \frac{1}{2} a t^2 \amp = 6 \times 0.5 + 0.5\times (-5) \times 0.5^2 = 2.4\text{ m}.

statement.p: A skater after an initial push glides with a constant deceleration. He comes to a stop after going 120 m in 25\text{ sec}.
(a) Find his initial speed, i.e., immediately after the push.
(b) Find the deceleration during the free glide.
(c) How much distance did he cover in the first 12.5 sec?
(d) How much distance did he cover in the last 12.5 sec?

solution.title: a
solution.p:
With +x axis in the direction of motion, we have
\Delta x = 120 \text{ m},\ \ v_{fx} = 0,\ \ \Delta t = 25\text{ s}\equiv t.
Using \Delta x = v_{\text{av},x}\, \Delta t and v_{\text{av},x} = (v_{ix}+v_{fx})/2, we get
120\text{ m} = \dfrac{v_{ix} + 0 }{2} \times 25\text{ s}.
Therefore,
v_{ix} = 9.6\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
Now, we have
v_{ix} = 9.6\text{ m/s},\ \ a_x = - 0.384\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ \Delta t = 12.5\text{ s}\equiv t.
Therefore
\Delta x \amp = v_{ix} t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_x t^2 \amp = 9.6 \times 12.5 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times (-0.384) \times 12.5^2 = 90\text{ m}.

example.title: Constant Acceleration on an Inclined Plane

statement.p: A truck is parked on an inclined slippery road. Suddenly, the brake fails and the truck starts to slide down the incline. You notice that starting from rest, the truck has picked up a speed of 20.0 m/s over a period of 30.0 seconds.
(a) Assuming constant acceleration, how far has the truck moved in this time?
(b) What is the acceleration of the truck?

answer.p: (a) 300.0 m, (b) 0.67 \text{ m/s}^2 pointed down the incline.

solution.title: a
solution.p: Since we have a constant acceleration situation, it is easy to get average velocity from the initial and final velocities. Here, the initial velocity v_i = 0 since the truck was not moving initially, and the final velocity v_f = 20.0 m/s. v_{av} = \dfrac{0 + 20.0}{2} = 10.0 \text{ m/s}. Therefore, the distance moved in t = 30.0 sec: \Delta x = v_{av} t = 10.0 \text{ m/s} \times 30.0 \text{ s} = 300.0 \text{ m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p: To get a , we just use the velocities and time given. a = \dfrac{v_f - v_i }{t} = \dfrac{2}{3} \text{ m/s}^2. From the description, it is clear that truck's speed is picking up. Hence, the direction of the acceleration is same as the direction in which the truck is moving, which is down the inclined road.

example.title: Modeling a Varying Acceleration by Average Constant Acceleration

statement.p: A cheeta's acceleration varies during its motion over a wide range. An example is given in below. Even though, the real-life situation is complicated, we can get a lot of physics by modeling the motion as if the motion was a constant acceleration motion, by replacing the varying acceleration by an average acceleration value. You would, of course not get the exact values, but your answer will be in the right ball park.

Suppose, the average acceleration of a cheetah between t=0 and t = 30\text{ sec} is 2.2\text{ m/s}^2. If cheetah started out at rest, what will be (a) the distance traveled and (b) speed at t = 30\text{ sec}?

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Since \Delta t and v_i are given to us, the following equation will give the displacement. Dropping x from subscript and writing t for \Delta t.
\Delta x = v_{i} t + \dfrac{1}{2} a_{\text{av}} t^2.
With the numerical values given, we get
\Delta x = 0 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times 2.2\times 30^2 = 990\text{ m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
The velocity at the final instant can be obtained by
v_{f} = v_{i} + a_{\text{av}}\, t = 2.2\times 30 = 66\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Practice with a Friend: A Car Speeding Up a Ramp

statement.p: To merge into a highway traffic, a car accelerates on a ramp of length 100\text{ m}. Starting from rest, the car makes it all the way to the end of the ramp in 5.4\text{ sec}. Asuming the acceleration was constant, (a) what is the acceleration of the car? (b) what would be the speed of the car at the end of the ramp?

exercise.title: Practice with a Friend: A Skier Racing Down a Hill

statement.p: A skier is racing down a hill at a constant acceleration. Assume straightline motion. She covers a distance of 100\,\text{m} in 5\text{ s}. At the end she is going at speed 30\text{ m/s}. (a) What was her acceleration? (b) What was her speed at the beginning?
